NEW: The Consumer Council has confirmed that electricity provider Budget Energy will increase its prices by 27% from May 27 2022. Budget Energy has around 90,000 customers in Northern Ireland. Its last increase (+29%) was introduced on November 26 2021.

SSE Airtricity put its NI electric tariff up by 3.9% in March 2021; 9.7% in August and 9% on December 1. It has around 170,000 NI customers. SSE has again blamed wholesale energy costs, which it says have "more than tripled compared to same time last year"
SSE Airtricity has announced a 33% price hike for its Northern Ireland electricity customers from June 1 2022. It will take the average household electric bill to around ¬£941

The proceedings relate to nine current and former staff linked to Invest NI‚Äôs GB/London FDI team. It‚Äôs understood those proceedings centre on terms of employment and not the HGS offer. INI was also notified of the tribunal proceedings some 18 months ago.

Invest NI has denied the HGS offer was ‚Äòheld back‚Äô to be entered against the new set of targets (from April 2021). Despite initially answering a number of questions on the matter, INI now states it will not comment any further on the HGS offer due to ‚Äúongoing legal proceedings‚Äù.

The context: Invest NI was approaching the end of the financial year, but crucially, the end of a four-year strategic target window in March 2021. It's understood it had already reached its four-year FDI target without the 563 HGS jobs.

Invest NI's two bids under the UK's new CRF were for innovation and R&D schemes. Both were rejected by the Dept for Levelling Up on a long list of 51 rejections that includes the likes of Catalyst, NI Screen, Cinemagic and even DAERA.

Officials at the Dept for the Economy recently told MLAs that Invest NI's funding is being cut by c¬£23m per year, largely due to the loss of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), which funded innovation and R&D programmes at Invest NI.
The Dept for Levelling Up has also published a list of the 51 failed applications for the CRF in NI. Crucially that list reveals Invest NI was rejected for two separate bids. Why is that important?
The Dept for Levelling Up said: ‚ÄúThe prospectus made clear that applicants need not be based in the country or region in which the project is delivered.‚Äù

TieTa has since branched into other call centre-based services. The Dept for Levelling Up has awarded it ¬£1.82 for a 'post-Covid small business success program' in Northern Ireland ironically called 'Voice For Locals'

MyJar Ltd collapsed into administration in December 2020. During restructuring and rebranding across 2020 and 2021, TXT Services became TieTa and changed ownership. Companies House currently lists three people with significant control of TieTa, all three have addresses in Monaco.

Previously known as TXT Services Ltd, TieTa was part of the MyJar Group. It started as the customer services arm for sister firm MyJar Ltd, which specialised in short-term loans. The FCA has described MyJar as ‚Äúa high cost short term lender, otherwise known as a payday lender‚Äù.
TieTa, which has no physical presence in the north, was awarded ¬£1.82m, more than double that of the next award to UU and 3x what QUB received (third largest allocation). Who is TieTa?

N Ireland took a 6% share of the ¬£220m pot = ¬£12.36m, which was paid out in 31 allocations. By far the biggest allocation when to a call centre company based in Banbury that most people in NI probably won't have heard of: TieTa UK.

The CRF is under the control of the Dept for Levelling Up, headed by Michael Gove. Unlike in other parts of the UK, where local authorities submitted bids, applications in N Ireland (including businesses) were able to apply directly.

Given the fact that circa 1.4 million are eligible for the card, it will be a remarkable feat if the online portal does not crash under the volume of applications on September 27.

DfE states cards will arrive 7-10 days after submitting application. But NI Direct guidance says it "could take several weeks as it will take time to process and check the large volume of applications as well as manufacture and issue the cards to everyone who has been verified".

Would seem then that students in England etc, can apply if on electoral register at home, or if they are registered at home with DVA etc. Cards just need to be activated by text or through an automated telephone service. Can only be spent in NI of course.

You will be able to apply on behalf of other people. Official guidance states "You can only do this for a limited number of people such as your parents, siblings or close relatives before the system will reject any further applications from you on behalf of others."

@michaeljardine @janeinator @brendanhughes64 @BBCRichardM Yet to be clarified, but my guess is retailers won't be ID-ing shoppers against the name on the card. It's also contactless. Whole idea is to boost spending - drive economy. So less on who spends, more on the fact it is spent in local shops etc.

How long will it take to process 1.4m HSS apps? DfE hasn't clarified how long cards will last. Two months was suggested previously. If the case, guidance below suggests it would need to rollout mid-Sept for max effectiveness. Otherwise, could we see it reduced to 4-6 weeks? https://t.co/VAqE7hBVXQ

The timing issue is potentially problematic for DfE. The whole point of the HSS is to stimulate spending in a lull. Traditionally August is a weak month for retail (albeit trad spending trends are out the window in 2021). But the scheme will need to end before Black Friday.
Retail Economics does concede that 'prioritising the effective launch of the scheme should take precedence over our recommendations of timing to maximise its effectiveness'.

The Retail Economics report commissioned by DfE recommends the scheme (expected to span 2 months) should run August to October. Economy Minister Gordon Lyons says the Autumn rollout 'aligns well to Retail Economics' recommendations on optimal timing'.

Of course furlough is still very much with us (106.5k jobs at end of Feb) and we can expect a spike in unemployment when that ends. But the forecasts have been revised *considerably* down from what was being predicted last year.

Coupled with the NIJobs data out this morning showing a 'v-shaped' recovery of sorts in the recruitment market during Q1 2021 (albeit skewed to health and IT), there's definitely some signs for optimism.

Stand out figure for me in today's jobs data is 170. That's the total number of redundancies proposed by NI employers in the first quarter of 2021. According to NISRA it's the lowest three month total since 2007. For context 5,115 redundancies were proposed over June-August 2020.

While the payments will come in the 2021/22 financial year, Conor Murphy has confirmed that the funding for the three schemes will come from the remaining Covid-19 funding in the current financial year (2020/21).

DoF has said the ¬£5k/¬£10k payments will be automatic (already vetted in LD1 grants). It will include takeaways and essential retail currently allowed to remain open. Small manufacturers, small prof services, dentists, physios etc also qualify

‚ñ™Ô∏è¬£10k 'top-up' is for businesses that received the ¬£25k retail/tourism/hospitality/leisure grant in LD1 - but have been omitted from LRSS/CRBSS Part B (est 1,600 businesses)
‚ñ™Ô∏è¬£5k for businesses (approx 16,000) that received ¬£10k small biz grant in LD1 but omitted from LRSS etc
¬£25k for medium-sized manufacturers (NAV ¬£15,001-¬£51k) will be automatic. LPS has already has vetted around 1,100 businesses from previous rates schemes - so payments will be automatic.

¬£50k grant will be application-based for businesses (NAV>¬£51k) eligible for 12 month rates holiday, eg: shops (not large food), car showrooms, garden centres, gyms. Anticipated 1,600 will qualify. Firms getting other support grants are omitted.

Total package just announced by Finance Minister Conor Murphy is worth approx ¬£178m. It's anticipated that around 20,000 businesses will qualify. With payments expected to start from April. The LRSS will continue to pay out in tandem with the lockdown restrictions.

Bad news for Belfast Intl, but Ryanair's move is massive for City Airport (and outgoing CEO Brian Ambrose) - almost a year to the day since losing anchor airline Flybe and 80% of flights. Most routes since replaced, with Aer Lingus setting up a new regional hub at the airport.

Ryanair's announcement makes no reference to its existing mothballed operation at Belfast International. Unclear what the status is of routes such as London Stansted, Manchester, Gdansk, Krakow, Warsaw Modlin and Malta.

Ryanair has now confirmed its return to Belfast City Airport with 8 summer routes: Services will include Malaga (7 weekly), Mallorca (7w), Faro (7w), Alicante (7w), Barcelona (5w), Ibiza (2w), Milan Bergamo (2w) and Valencia (2w).

It's unclear what Ryanair has in store for its NI to GB flights. Belfast to London Stansted is completely gone from its booking website, with no return date for BFS to Manchester. Similarly no return dates for City of Derry to Liverpool and Edinburgh.

Ryanair‚Äôs operation at Belfast Intl has been grounded since January. Six routes were due to return in spring/summer: Krakow, Bergamo, Warsaw, Gdansk, Malaga and Alicante. Three of those routes now flying from Belfast City. Faro and Barcelona also previously operated from the Intl
